However, I think that the purpose of the honorable member's question may be met by the information that is available. This relates to the files of the individual claims transmitted to, and dealt with in, the Treasury.

item.para: During a review in December, 1958, it was established that on the average approximately 700 files were forwarded for attention each month. At 30th June, 1959, there were 825 files awaiting attention;
From 1st July, 1959 to 31st December, 1959 5,937 files were dealt with in the Treasury. From 1st January, 1960 to 30th September, the figure is 7,136;
At 30th September, 1960 there were 67 files awaiting attention. There were also 78 files on which outward correspondence was being typed.

Following the review of December, 1958, six new positions were sought on 30th January, 1959. The recommendation for the creation of these positions was received by the Treasury on 6th July, 1959. Steps have been taken for the appointment of officers to these positions. In the interim experienced staff were diverted from other duties and substantial overtime was worked by the staff.

talk.start.para: asked the Acting Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: What authority determines the volume of Commonwealth notes to be put into circulation from time to time in order to meet the nation's requirements?
What basic principles are applied by this authority in making its decisions?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: The Australian note issue is administered by the Reserve Bank of Australia through its Note Issue Department.
The volume of notes in circulation is determined solely in accordance with the fluctuating demand of the public for note currency for its transactions and liquidity requirements.

talk.start.para: - On 20th September, the honorable member for Yarra {Mr. Cairns) asked the Acting Treasurer a question without notice regarding the observance by certain financial institutions of policy determinations by the Reserve Bank. The Acting Treasurer at the time undertook to obtain and to provide the relevant facts. I am now able to supply the following answer: -

quote.para: By Banking (Exemption) Orders Nos. 1 and 5 published in the Commonwealth Gazette on 14th January, 1960, and 15th September, 1960, respectively, a number of building societies, and pastoral, hire purchase, life assurance and other finance companies were exempted under section 11 of the Banking Act 1959 from compliance with sections 7 and 8 of that act. These exemptions are subject to a condition requiring the bodies concerned to comply with any directions given them by the Reserve Bank with regard to the policy to be followed in making advances in the course of banking business carried on by them. The Reserve Bank has not issued any directions of that character.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's questions is as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice -

item.para: How many officers of his department are attached to the Administration of the Territory of New Guinea?
What is the number of officers attached to the Department of Law in the Territory?
How many of these officers are qualified by law?
What are the duties of that department?
Has the. Administrator made any request for additional staff in his Department of Law? If so, when and with what result?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: None. The Public Service of Papua and New Guinea is quite separate from the Commonwealth Public Service. Officers of either service may be seconded for short terms to the other, but there are no secondments of officers from the Department of Territories. At 31st August, 1960, there were 4,065 officers and employees in the Papua and New Guinea Service.
Sixty-three (establishment 81).
Twenty-four.

The functions of the Secretary for Law include: Legal adviser of the Administrator and heads of departments, the administration of justice and certain statutory and common law powers and responsibility for the following: -
Crown Law Office - Advisings, prosecutions, legal drafting.
Supreme Court Registry - Probate and succession matters, taxation of costs, judgments, sheriff, jury lists, insolvency, court records and court registers.
Registar-General's Office - Land titles, companies office and registration, business names registration, Registrar of Births, Deaths and Marriages.
Public Curator's Office - Matters concerning deceased estates, estates of insolvent persons and affairs of insane persons.
Titles Commissioner's Office - Restoration of titles to land and mining tenements lost during the 1939-45 war.
Native Lands Commissioner's Office - Registration of native land.
Stipendiary Magistrates Court - Hearing of simple offences, claims to value of £250 and preliminary hearing of indictable offences.
Public Solicitors Office - Provisions of defence counsel for natives and impecunious persons and in appeals and civil and criminal jurisdiction.

The Administrator requested three additional positions of Legal Officer, Grade 2, on 6th January, 1960, and these were approved by me on 2nd February, 1960. Legal officers are recruited as and when suitable candidates become available, the present specialist recruitment target being for seven legal officers against which four candidates are now being considered for appointment.

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice -

item.para: Are television and radio broadcasting stations obliged to obtain copies of the script used by all persons telecasting or broadcasting speeches, statements, or comments, and to record group discussions?
If so, how long are copies of the script and records retained, and are they available for perusal or replay, as the case may be, by any interested person?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.para: Section 117A of the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942-1960 provides that the Australian Broadcasting Commission and licencees of television and broadcasting stations shall cause a record to be made either in writing or by means of a device for recording sound of any matter broadcast or televised relating to a political subject or current affairs, being matter that is in the form of news, an address, a statement, a commentary or a discussion, insofar as it consists of sound.

The section further requires that such record shall ordinarily be retained for a period of six weeks or for such longer period as the Minister, in special circumstances, directs. There are special provisions for the retention for a longer period of a record of matter which may be admissible in evidence in court proceedings or which is of historic interest The act makes no provision for records of matter broadcast or televised to be made available to the public. Section 117a. was inserted in the. act by the amending act of 1960, and is to come into operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation. The section has not yet come into operation.
